Huggins: Back Up to the Farm, Full Circle
By KEN BAKALAR
"Hollingsworth liked to talk and I was a good
listener." William Huggins still is. There are two
chairs in his office; the one behind the desk is a
straight-backed secretary's chair. The one in front
Of the desk, the visitor's chair, is high-backed, deep,
and covered in black leather.
Hollingsworth and Huggins went to school
together. Hollingsworth was an amateur radio
Operator; when he talked, Huggins listened and
learned enough to earn his baccalaureate degree in
electrical engineering from Oregon State College in
1941.
Hollingsworth is now a vice-president of the
Boeing Aircraft Corporation; Dr. Huggins chairs
the Electrical Engineering Department at Johns
Hopkins.
"I like to teach." Huggins has a broad, kind smile
and soft eyes underneath thinning, curly gray hair.
"There is a tremendous emotional satisfaction in
making meaningful and important and useful
ideas."
His voice is soft and resonant, and he leans forward to emphasize his point. "I have always enjoyed my work with undergraduates more than my
work with graduate students."
But he thinks he is bragging about his skills.
Lowering his eyes and leaning back, he says, "I'm
being too generous with myself." He explains that
because he was invited here as a full professor, he
escaped the "publish or perish" problems of junior
faculty members who must concentrate on their
research to the detriment of their students.
Dr. Huggins was born in Rupert, Idaho, a small

'town in the southern part of the state on the edge of
the desert. When his father died at the beginning of
the Depression, the family moved to Eugene,
Oregon.
"Work has been a pretty large hunk of my life. I
used to play the piano, but that has gone by the way.
But work for me has never really been work. I've
always enjoyed it.

"As you get older, you see more and more things

Dr. Huggins finds that the duties of a department
chairman fill his day. "Don't ask me what sort of
,research I'm getting done. I'm too busy with other
things." Does he regret the loss? "No, no, it has to
be done.
"But I have a theory," he says, and shakes his
head in a gesture of regret. "Each of us has only a
certain number of starts in him. Switching from
project to project the way I do, I see this pile of blue
chips dwindling away. The energy wasted is
'tremendous."

"One of the important things you have to learn is
what not to do. The tragedy is, the more innovative a
person is, the harder it is to get anything done."
It is hard to say whether Dr. Huggins considers
himself innovative. But the opinion of his peers is
unanimous. For example, Dr. Robert Rich of APL:
"This is a man who does so many things so well, I
don't know where to begin. It doesn't matter which
of the many intellectual doors you approach him

Ten years ago, Dr. Huggins became part owner of
a farm on the Lost River about forty miles from Sun
Valley, Idaho. The farm's 230 acres graze 140 head
of beef cattle and produce 4000 sacks of seed potatos
each year. His manner becomes lighter when he
talks of the farm. He thumbs through envelopes of
photographs, looking for one of the farm, and is
annoyed when he can't find it. "More and more
these days," he says, "my interests are turning
from signal analysis to farming . . ."

diversity. Smaller schools offer more. Use
the English Department as an example:
Hopkins offers 12 courses. Swarthmore with
1100 students, offers 23; Amherst offers 14;

these schools are larger than Hopkins and

incongruity of the comparison points out that
